awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Solar Neutrino Science with Borexino
awd_abstract_narration:
Solar neutrino research has already discovered massive neutrinos and flavor mixing and is moving into an era where precision measurements can provide a unique probe of the structure and composition of the Sun. The carbon-nitrogen-oxygen (CNO) cycle is one of the fusion reactions by which stars convert hydrogen to helium, releasing electron-neutrinos. The CNO neutrino flux depends on the abundance of carbon in the core of the Sun. A measurement of the CNO flux would be the first direct measurement of the solar metallicity (the abundance of elements other than hydrogen or helium) in the core of the Sun. It could test the fundamental assumption of homogeneity in the Sun and provide crucial information regarding opacities in the solar interior that are important for helioseismology. Such studies could thus have a great impact on our understanding of the Sun, stellar astrophysics, the link between planetary and stellar formation, as well as basic neutrino physics. Borexino is a liquid scintillator detector, located at the Gran Sasso National Laboratory in Italy, with a unique sensitivity to solar neutrinos.

The Borexino research program has involved many undergraduate and graduate students. Mentoring and training young researchers at the collaborating institutions and other schools has always been a high priority. The three groups will continue to involve undergraduate students in this research and disseminate research to the broader community.

The research funded here plans to measure neutrinos from the catalytic reactions on 12-C and 15-N which convert four protons to 4-He, producing neutrinos from the beta decays of 13-N and 15-O. The CN neutrino flux depends directly on the abundance of 12-C and 15-N in the core of the Sun, and their measurement would be the first direct measurement of the metallicity (elements heavier than 4-He), in the core of the Sun. This result will be far reaching because the solar composition is the basis for many important topics in astrophysics, including stellar structure, stellar evolution, and stellar atmospheres, to name a few. In addition, it will address the 'solar composition problem', the apparent disagreement in metallicity determined from recent advances in analysis of solar photospheric optical spectra, which favors a low metallicity, and advances in helioseismology, which favors high metallicity. Since modifications of the Standard Solar Model to explain a non-uniform solar composition have not been very successful, the 'solar composition problem' remains an unexplained flaw in the Standard Solar Model.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Unlike photons, neutrinos escape immediately from the Sun's core at nearly the speed of light, thus preserving real-time information from the fusion reactions powering the Sun.  For this reason, solar neutrinos are the most effective and direct probes for the study of the Sun interior.

Established in the 1990s, the Borexino experiment, located at the Gran Sasso National Laboratory in Italy, features a liquid scintillator detector with a unique sensitivity to solar neutrinos.  Thanks to the unprecedented level of radiopurity achieved for its scintillator target, Borexino performed an accurate measurement of nearly the entire spectrum of solar neutrinos.  Throughout the thirty years span from the initial proposal through project completion, the Borexino research program provided training opportunities for many undergraduate and graduate students in U.S. Universities and notably at Princeton University, with a positive impact on training of women and minority students in physics and engineering.  Support from the U.S. National Science Foundation was crucial to achieve the science and technology results as well as to foster the associated training program.

Following early campaigns resulting in the precision measurements of most of the neutrino sources from the basic pp solar fusion cycle, in the last few years of its program the Borexino Collaboration achieved the first (and insofar sole) measurement of neutrinos from the Carbon-Nitrogen-Oxygen (CNO) cycle, the secondary fusion cycle active in the Sun's core (also, the dominant cycle in larger stars).  The CNO solar neutrino flux depends critically on the abundance of the solar metallicity (the abundance of elements other than hydrogen or helium).  Its direct measurement, at long thought to be unattainable, is the only experimental avenue for a direct assessment of solar metallicity, enabling to test fundamental assumptions of homogeneity in the Sun as well as to provide crucial information regarding opacities in the solar interior that are important for helioseismology.  The precision measurement of CNO neutrinos performed by Borexino, along with the high precision mesurements of several neutrino sources from the pp cycle, had an outsize impact on our understanding of the Sun, of stellar astrophysics, of the link between planetary and stellar formation, as well as of basic neutrino physics.

The Borexino experiment concluded its operation in October 2021.

The main results of the project are the most precise measurement of the pp solar neutrino spectrum and the first and sole experimental proof of the CNO solar fusion cycle obtained by detecting CNO solar neutrinos.  The Borexino project also advanced purification techniques to remove radioactive isotopes from organic liquids, water, and other detector construction materials, benefitting existing and future solar neutrino detectors and influencing strategies and technological choices for the fields of direct dark matter searches and neutrinoless double beta decay searches.
